p: By examining the comparison of closely allied species in Figure 3, a distinct splitting of P. lanceolata Domin is evident. One group recognises kessane as the dominant sesquiterpene oxide and globulol (branch C; Figure 3) as the dominant sesquiterpene alcohol. The other group is the converse of this (branch B; Figure 3). In this regard, the phrase named P. sp. Blue Mountains ( P. sp. aff. rotundifolia) was placed in the high Z-dihydroagarofuran branch ( Figure 3).
